description: Works just fine. Easy to use. Easy to configure username/password when writing image and lets you enable SSL. Makes it easy to configure a headless Pi.
shows progressbars for writing and for verifying, but at the end, the sd card is unchanged. maybe something about permissions..
I have tried to run this imager in an Ubuntu 18.04 machine and stopped in the middle of the process destroying the SD card...
udisks seem to be a problem

I originally downloaded this app at version 1.3, and it appeared to write a disk image very quickly, but had actually failed to write it correctly. After updating to version 1.4, the app now appears to work correctly.

Regardless, I use GNOME and the GNOME disk utility has a capable disk image writer, obviating my need for this. Now the app is requesting an additional "access system devices files" in order to be updated, which I would assume means access to `/dev` and I'm not sure how it got by without that access before, I'm probably going to uninstall it and use the GNOME disk utility in its stead. After all, this utility is not packaged by the Raspberry Pi team or foundation, and thus may be subject to a maintainer (intentionally or otherwise) tampering with it.
Cool UI, but 'cannot open storage device' all the time
summary: Cool UI, but 'cannot open storage device' all the time

Amazing and rock solid program that does what it says and says what it does.

If only it could write IMG files. I know that's not what it's meant for, but if it could back up SD cards to IMG files, it would one of the most useful apps in your drawer.
A great and easy utility for writing images to SD Cards, especially for Raspberry Pi devices. Automatically downloads Pi OS's for you, including non official ones such as RetroPi, etc
It does exactly what it says and works the same as on macOS, which is a plus as not all apps have the same experience cross-platform.

You need to run this program as root.
Type "sudo -i" and run this program from it.
It worked for me.
